subject: Learning
title: Early Academics: Earlier Isn't Always Better
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Early Academics: Earlier Isn't Always Better.

hook.text: A preschool teaches reading to three-year-olds. Parents love it. Developmental scientists worry.

buildup.text: Pushing formal academics in preschool is popular but not supported by developmental research.

discovery.text: Play-based learning develops executive function, social skills, and creativityâ€”all of which predict later success.

twist.text: Countries that start formal reading instruction at 7 (like Finland) outperform those that start at 5.

climax.text: Early academic pressure can increase anxiety and reduce motivation without lasting academic gains.

punchline.text: Starting earlier doesn't mean finishing ahead.

quiz.question: What does research say about early academic instruction in preschool?
options: Play-based learning is more effective for long-term development
Earlier formal instruction always leads to higher achievement
Reading must begin before age 4 for success
